description.purpose: What is to be done by this control
description.composition: What happens if the control is operated
description.effect: What happens if the control is operated

rivals.Rival 1: What other controls are similar, what is their distinction

usage.1: Where and when an element is to be used or not.

interaction.2: How the interaction with this object takes place.

wording.3: How the wording of labels or captions must be.

ordering.5: How different elements of this instance are to be ordered.

style.4: How this element should look like.

responsiveness.6: How this element behaves on changing screen sizes

accessibility.7: How this element is made accessible

description.purpose: Counter inform users about the quantity of items indicated by a glyph.
description.composition: Counters consist of a number and some background color and are placed one the 'end of the line' in reading direction of the item they state the count for.
description.effect: Counters convey information, they are not interactive.

usage.1: A counter MUST only be used in combination with a glyph.

composition.1: A counter MUST contain exactly one number greater than zero and no other characters.

GlyphFactoryGlyph.title: Glyph

description.purpose: Glyphs map a generally known concept or symbol to a specific concept in ILIAS. Glyphs are used when space is scarce.
description.composition: A glyph is a typographical character that represents something else. As any other typographical character, they can be manipulated by regular CSS. If hovered they change their background to indicate possible interactions.
description.effect: Glyphs act as trigger for some action such as opening a certain Overlay type or as shortcut.

rivals.icon: Standalone Icons are not interactive. Icons can be in an interactive container however. Icons merely serve as additional hint of the functionality described by some title. Glyphs are visually distinguished from object icons: they are monochrome.

GlyphFactoryGlyph.background: "In typography, a glyph is an elemental symbol within an agreed set of symbols, intended to represent a readable character for the purposes of writing and thereby expressing thoughts, ideas and concepts." (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glyph) Lidwell states that such symbols are used "to improve the recognition and recall of signs and controls".

usage.1: Glyphs MUST NOT be used in content titles.
usage.2: Glyphs MUST be used for cross-sectional functionality such as mail for example and NOT for representing objects.
usage.3: Glyphs SHOULD be used for very simple tasks that are repeated at many places throughout the system.
usage.4: Services such as mail MAY be represented by a glyph AND an icon.

style.1: All Glyphs MUST be taken from the Bootstrap Glyphicon Halflings set. Exceptions MUST be approved by the JF.

accessibility.1: The functionality triggered by the Glyph must be indicated to screen readers with by the attribute aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute.

ButtonFactoryButton.title: Button

description.purpose: Buttons trigger interactions that change the system’s status. Usually Buttons are contained in an Input Collection. The Toolbar is the main exception to this rule, since buttons in the Toolbar might also perform view changes.
description.composition: Button is a clickable, graphically obtrusive control element. It can bear text.
description.effect: On-click, the action indicated by the button is carried out.

rivals.glyph: Glyphs are used if the enclosing Container Collection can not provide enough space for textual information or if such an information would clutter the screen.
rivals.links: Links are used to trigger Interactions that do not change the systems status. They are usually contained inside a Navigational Collection.

ButtonFactoryButton.background: Wording rules have been inspired by the iOS Human Interface Guidelines (UI-Elements->Controls->System Button) Style rules have been inspired from the GNOME Human Interface Guidelines->Buttons.

usage.1: Buttons MUST NOT be used inside a Textual Paragraph.

interaction.1: A Button SHOULD trigger an action. Only in Toolbars, Buttons MAY also change the view.
interaction.2: If an action is temporarily not available, Buttons MUST be disabled by setting as type 'disabled'.

wording.1: The caption of a Button SHOULD contain no more than two words.
wording.2: The wording of the button SHOULD describe the action the button performs by using a verb or a verb phrase.
wording.3: Every word except articles, coordinating conjunctions and prepositions of four or fewer letters MUST be capitalized.
wording.4: For standard events such as saving or canceling the existing standard terms MUST be used if possible: Save, Cancel, Delete, Cut, Copy.
wording.5: There are cases where a non-standard label such as “Send Mail” for saving and sending the input of a specific form might deviate from the standard. These cases MUST however specifically justified.

style.1: If Text is used inside a Button, the Button MUST be at least six characters wide.

accessibility.1: DOM elements of type "button" MUST be used to properly identify an element as a Button if there is no good reason to do otherwise.
accessibility.2: Button DOM elements MUST either be of type "button", of type "a" accompanied with the aria-role “Button” or input along with the type attribute “button” or "submit".

description.purpose:
A card is a flexible content container for small chunks of structured data.
 Cards are often used in so-called Decks which are a gallery of Cards.
description.composition: Cards contain a header, which often includes an Image or Icon and a Title as well as possible actions as Default Buttons and 0 to n sections that may contain further links and buttons.
description.effect: Cards may contain Interaction Triggers.

rivals.Heading Panel: Heading Panels fill up the complete available width in the Center Content Section. Multiple Heading Panels are stacked vertically.
rivals.Block Panels: Block Panels are used in Sidebars

composition.2: Cards SHOULD contain an Image or Icon in the header section.

style.1: Sections of  Cards MUST be separated by Dividers.

accessibility.1: If multiple Cards are used, they MUST be contained in a Deck.

description.purpose: Images are used for previous of downloads or view of user images.
Text is read by users and transmits informative messages to them.
description.composition: Text Elements may only contain characters.

wording.1: Reading is hard thus all written information displayed to the user SHOULD be as short and as non-technical as possible.

description.purpose: Links are navigational controls and mainly open a new view. A ‘view’ is a context, a new and different screen compared to where the user clicked the link. Mostly Links trigger interactions that do not leave a permanent change on the system. There are exceptions to this rule. Links are used in Input Pickers for example, which then result in some input for forms to be stored on the backend.
description.composition: Links are textual elements distinguished from other text by their color. Links appear typically in lists of objects displaying their title and opening the object if clicked on. In ILIAS links that are part of the content are underlined while links that are controls are not underlined but merely colored differently.
description.effect: The exact effect triggered by clicking on the Link depends on its exact context.

rivals.Buttons: Links are strongly related to Buttons. See the Button entry for an explanation about their difference.
rivals.Glyphs: Are used if the enclosing Container Collection can not provide enough information for textual information or if such an information would clutter the screen.

composition.1: Links SHOULD only be used for navigational interactions or view changes.
composition.2: Links MAY be used for selecting objects for carrying out an action (e.g. Picker).

style.1: Links that are part of (user generated) content MUST be underlined, others MUST NOT.

description.purpose: Listings are used to structure textual information.
Panels are used to group titled Content.
description.composition: Panels consist of a header and content section.
description.effect: The effect of interaction with panels heavily depends on their content.

wording.2: Panels MUST form one Gestalt and so build a perceivable cluster of information

description.purpose: Can hold any content.

usage.1: Do only this component to solve legacy issues.

description.purpose: The Status counter is used to display information about the total number of some items like users active on the system or total number of comments.
description.composition: The Status Counter is a non-obstrusive Counter.
description.effect: Status Counters convey information, they are not interactive.

style.1: The Status Counter MUST be displayed on the lower right of the item it accompanies.
style.2: The Status Counter SHOULD have a non-obstrusive background color, such as grey.

description.purpose: Novelty counters inform users about the arrival or creation of new items of the kind indicated by the accompanying glyph.
description.composition: A Novelty Counter is an obtrusive counter.
description.effect: They count down / disappear as soon as the change has been consulted by the user.

usage.1: The Novelty Counter MAY be used with the Status Counter.

interaction.2: There MUST be a way for the user to consult the changes indicated by the counter.
interaction.3: After the consultation, the Novelty Counter SHOULD disappear or the number it contains is reduced by one.
interaction.4: Depending on the content, the reduced number MAY be added in an additional Status Counter.

style.5: The Novelty Counter MUST be displayed on the top at the 'end of the line' in reading direction of the item it accompanies. This would be top right for latin script and top left for arabic script.
style.6: The Novelty Counter SHOULD have an obstrusive background color, such as red or orange.

description.purpose: The Settings Glyph triggers opening a Dropdown to edit settings of the displayed block.
description.composition: The Settings Glyph uses the glyphicon-cog.
description.effect: Upon clicking a settings Dropdown is opened.

usage.1: The Settings Glyph MUST only be used in Blocks.

description.purpose: The Collapse Glyph is used to trigger the collapsing of some neighbouring Container Collection such as a the content of a Dropdown or an Accordion currently shown.
description.composition: The Collapse Glyph is composed of a triangle pointing to the bottom indicating that content is currently shown.
description.effect: Clicking the Collapse Glyph hides the display of some Container Collection.

rivals.Expand Glyph: The Expand Glyphs triggers the display of some Container Collection.
rivals.Previous Glyph: The Previous/Next Glyph opens a completely new view. It serves a navigational purpose.

usage.1: The Collapse Glyph MUST indicate if the toggled Container Collection is visible or not.

description.purpose: The Expand Glyph is used to trigger the display of some neighbouring Container Collection such as a the content of a Dropdown or an Accordion currently shown.
description.composition: The Expand Glyph is composed of a triangle pointing to the right indicating that content is currently shown.
description.effect: Clicking the Expand Glyph displays some Container Collection.

rivals.Collapse Glyph: The Collapse Glyphs hides the display of some Container Collection.
rivals.Previous Glyph: The Previous/Next Glyph opens a completely new view. It serves a navigational purpose.

usage.1: The Expand Glyph MUST indicate if the toggled Container Collection is visible or not.

description.purpose: The glyphed add-button serves as stand-in for the respective textual buttons in very crowded screens. It allows adding a new item.
description.composition: The Add Glyph uses the glyphicon-plus-sign.
description.effect: Clicking on the Add Glyph adds a new input to a form or an event to the calendar.

usage.1: The Add Glyph SHOULD not come without a Remove Glyph and vice versa. Because either there is not enough place for textual buttons or there is place. Exceptions to this rule, such as the Calendar, where only elements can be added in a certain place are possible, are to be run through the Jour Fixe.
usage.2: The Add Glyph stands for an Action and SHOULD be placed in the action column of a form.
usage.3: The Add Glyph MUST not be used to add lines to tables.

interaction.1: Newly added items MUST be placed below the line in which the Add Glyph has been clicked

description.purpose: The Remove Glyph serves as stand-in for the respective textual buttons in very crowded screens. It allows removing an item.
description.composition: The Remove Glyph uses the glyphicon-plus-sign.
description.effect: Clicking on the Remove Glyph adds a new input to a form or an event to the calendar.

usage.1: The Remove Glyph SHOULD not come without a glyphed Add Glyph and vice versa. Because either there is not enough place for textual buttons or there is place. Exceptions to this rule, such as the Calendar, where only elements can be added in a certain place are possible, are to be run through the Jour Fixe.
usage.2: The Remove Glyph stands for an Action and SHOULD be placed in the action column of a form.
usage.3: The Remove Glyph MUST not be used to add lines to tables.

description.purpose: The Up Glyph allows for manually arranging rows in tables embedded in forms. It allows moving an item up.
description.composition: The Up Glyph uses the glyphicon-circle-arrow-up. The Up Glyph can be combined with the Add/Remove Glyph.
description.effect: Clicking on the Up Glyph moves an item up.

usage.1: The Up Glyph MUST NOT be used to sort tables. There is an established sorting control for that.
usage.2: The Up Glyph SHOULD not come without a Down and vice versa.
usage.3: The Up Glyph is an action and SHOULD be listed in the action column of a form.

description.purpose: The Down Glyph allows for manually arranging rows in tables embedded in forms. It allows moving an item down.
description.composition: The Down Glyph uses the glyphicon-circle-arrow-down. The Down Glyph can be combined with the Add/Remove Glyph.
description.effect: Clicking on the Down Glyph moves an item up.

usage.1: The Down Glyph MUST NOT be used to sort tables. There is an established sorting control for that.
usage.2: The Down Glyph SHOULD not come without a Up and vice versa.
usage.3: The Down Glyph is an action and SHOULD be listed in the action column of a form.

description.purpose: The Back Glyph indicates a possible change of the view. The view change leads back to some previous view.
description.composition: The chevron-left glyphicon is used.
description.effect: The click on a Back Glyph leads back to a previous view.

usage.1: Back and Next Buttons MUST be accompanied by the respective Back/Next Glyph.

style.1: If clicking on the Back/Next GLYPH opens a new view of an object, the Next Glyph MUST be used.
style.2: If clicking on the Back/Next GLYPH opens a previous view of an object, the Back Glyph MUST be used.

description.purpose: The Next Glyph indicates a possible change of the view. The view change leads back to some previous view.
description.composition: The chevron-right glyphicon is used.
description.effect: The click on a Next Glyph opens a new view.

usage.1: Back and Next Buttons MUST be accompanied by the respective Back/Next Glyph.

style.1: If clicking on the Back/Next GLYPH opens a new view of an object, the Next Glyph MUST be used.
style.2: If clicking on the Back/Next GLYPH opens a previous view of an object, the Back Glyph MUST be used.

description.purpose: The Sorting Glyphs indicate the sorting direction of a column in a table as ascending (up) or descending (down). It is a toggle reversing the ordering of a column.
description.composition: The Sort Ascending Glyph uses glyphicon-arrow-up.
description.effect: Clicking the Sort Ascending Glyph reverses the direction of ordering in a table.

description.purpose: The Sorting Glyphs indicate the sorting direction of a column in a table as ascending (up) or descending (down). It is a toggle reversing the ordering of a column.
description.composition: The Sort Descending Glyph uses glyphicon-arrow-descending.
description.effect: Clicking the Sort Descending Glyph reverses the direction of ordering in a table.

description.purpose: The User Glyph triggers the “Who is online?” Popover in the Top Navigation. The User Glyph indicates the number of pending contact requests and users online via the the Novelty Counter and Status Counter respectively.
description.composition: The User Glyph uses the glyphicon-user.
description.effect: Clicking the User Glyph opens the “Who is online?” Popover.

accessibility.1: The aria-label MUST be ‘Show who is online'.

description.purpose: The Mail Glyph provides a shortcut to the mail service. The Mail Glyph indicates the number of new mails received.
description.composition: The Mail Glyph uses the glyphicon-envelope.
description.effect: Upon clicking on the Mail Glyph the user is transferred to the full-screen mail service.

rivals.Mail Icon: The Mail Icon is used to indicate the user is currently located in the Mail service The Mail Glyph acts as shortcut to the Mail service.

description.purpose: The Notification Glyph allows users to activate / deactivate the notification service for a specific object or sub-item. It is a toggle indicating by colour  whether it is activated or not.
description.composition: The Notification Glyph uses the glyphicon-bell in link-color if notifications are not active or brand-warning color if they are.
description.effect: Upon clicking the notification activation is toggled: Clicking the Notification Glyph activates respectively deactivates the notification service for the current object or sub-item.

usage.1: The Notification Glyph MUST only be used in the Content Top Actions.

interaction.1: Clicking the Notification Glyph MUST toggle the activation of Notifications.

style.1: If notifications are activated the Notification Glyph MUST use the brand-warning color.

description.purpose: The Tag Glyph is used to indicate the possibility of adding tags to an object.
description.composition: The Tag Glyph uses the glyphicon-tag.
description.effect: Upon clicking the Round Trip Modal to add new Tags is opened.

composition.1: Novelty and Status Counter MUST show the amount of tags that has been given for an specific object.

description.purpose: The Note Glyph is used to indicate the possibilty of adding notes to an object.
description.composition: The Note Glyph uses the glyphicon-pushpin.
description.effect: Upon clicking the Round Trip Modal to add new notes is opened

composition.1: Novelty and Status Counter MUST show the amount of notes that has been given for an specific object.

description.purpose: The Comment Glyph is used to indicate the possibilty of adding comments to an object.
description.composition: The Comment Glyph uses the glyphicon-comment.
description.effect: Upon clicking the Round Trip Modal to add new comments is opened.

composition.1: Novelty and Status Counter MUST show the amount of comments that has been given for an specific object.

description.purpose: The standard button is the default button to be used in ILIAS. If there is no good reason using another button instance in ILIAS, this is the one that should be used.
description.composition: The standard button uses the primary bolor as background.

usage.1: Standard buttons MUST be used if there is no good reason using another instance.

ordering.1: The most important standard button SHOULD be first in reading direction if there are several buttons.
ordering.2: In the toolbar and in forms special regulations for the ordering of the buttons MAY apply.

responsiveness.1: The most important standard button in multi-action bars MUST be sticky (stay visible on small screens).

ButtonPrimaryPrimary.title: Primary

description.purpose: The primary button indicates the most important action on a screen. By definition there can only be one single “most important” action on any given screen and thus only one single primary button per screen.
description.composition: The background color is the btn-primary-color. This screen-unique button-color ensures that it stands out and attracts the user’s attention while there are several buttons competing for attention.
description.effect: In toolbars the primary button are required to be sticky, meaning they stay in view in the responsive view.

ButtonPrimaryPrimary.background: Tiddwell refers to the primary button as “prominent done button” and describes that “the button that finishes a transaction should be placed at the end of the visual flow; and is to be made big and well labeled.” She explains that “A well-understood, obvious last step gives your users a sense of closure. There’s no doubt that the transaction will be done when that button is clicked; don’t leave them hanging, wondering whether their work took effect”. The GNOME Human Interface Guidelines -> Buttons also describes a button indicated as most important for dialogs.

usage.1: Most pages SHOULD NOT have any Primary Button at all.
usage.2: There MUST no more than one Primary Button per page in ILIAS.
usage.3: The decision to make a Button a Primary Button MUST be confirmed by the JF.

description.purpose: The close button triggers the closing of some collection displayed temporarily such as an overlay.
description.composition: The close button is displayed without border.
description.effect: Clicking the close button closes the enclosing collection.

ordering.1: The Close Button MUST always be positioned in the top right of a collection.

accessibility.1: The functionality of the close button MUST be indicated for screen readers by an aria-label.

description.purpose: The standard image is used if there is no specific reason to use another specialized one.
Use if formated code needs to be represented in a readable manner including syntax highlighting.
description.composition: Contains formatted code.
description.effect: Renders the given code and highlights it syntax.

description.purpose: Unordered Lists are used to display a unordered set of textual elements.
description.composition: Unordered Lists are composed of a set of bullets labeling the listed items.

description.purpose: Ordered Lists are used to displayed a numbered set of textual elements. They are used if the order of the elements is relevant.
description.composition: Ordered Lists are composed of a set of numbers labeling the items enumerated.

description.purpose: Descriptive Lists are used to display key-value doubles of textual-information.
description.composition: Descriptive Lists are composed of a key acting as title describing the type of information being displayed underneath.

PanelBlock.title: Block

description.purpose: Block Panels are used to display global services in Sidebars or group content in the Center Content. The might also be used to perform some nested grouping inside a Heading Panel as used in the Bulletin.
description.composition: The header section might contain a cog to change some settings of the content displayed in the Block Panel.
description.effect: Panels on the personal Desktop are sortable and might be hidden through the Cog Glyph.

PanelBlock.background: Tiddwell describes the Pattern of “Collapsible Panels in which one can “Put secondary or optional material into panels that can be opened and closed by the user”. They work well to acompany a “Center Stage” where content needs to take visual priority. Hiding noncritical pieces of content helps to simplify the interface. When a user hides a module that supports the main content, it simply collapses, giving its space back over to the main content (or to whitespace). This is an example of the principle of progressive disclosure — show hidden content “just in time,” when and where the user needs it. She futher recommends “Collapsible Panels” for: (a) Content that annotates, modifies, explains, or otherwise supports the content in the main part of the page. (b) Services that may not be important enough for any of them to be open by default. Their value may vary a lot from user to user. Some will really want to see a particular service, and others won’t care about it at all. Even for one user, a service may be useful sometimes, but not other times. When it’s not open, its space is better used by the page’s main content. (c) Users that may want to open more than one service at the same time.

usage.1: Block Panels MIGHT be used inside Heading Panels to structure nested content.

interaction.2: Block Panel MIGHT be moveable per Drag and Drop

style.3: Block Panels MIGHT contain a cog to change settings of the content displayed inside the panel.

description.purpose: Bulletin display user-generated data combining text in lists, tables and sometimes  charts. Bulletins always draws from two distinct sources: the structure / scaffolding of the bulletins stems from user-generated content (i.e a question of a survey, a competence with levels) and is filled with user-generated content harvested by that very structure (i.e. participants’ answers to the question, self-evaluation of competence)
description.composition: They comprise the structured content used to harvest input and the harvested input alongside: the text of the harvesting structure is given in full length with a headline, label of subitems, text of subitems in bulleted lists. This may be followed by a table comprising or aggregating the harvested input. This might be followed by a picture or a graph.
description.effect: Bulletinss are predominantly used for displaying data. They may however comprise links or buttons.

usage.1: Bulletins are to be used when user generated content of two sources (i.e results, guidelines in a template) is to be displayed alongside each other .

interaction.3: Buttons MAY trigger actions or inline editing.
